t: It*p is a trustworthy statement: if any man aspires to the office of overseer, it is a fine work he desires to*i do.*i
An overseer, then, must be above reproach, the husband of one wife, temperate, prudent, respectable, hospitable, able to teach,
not addicted to wine or pugnacious, but gentle, peaceable, free from the love of money.
He*i must*i be*i one who manages his own household well, keeping his children under control with all dignity
(but if a man does not know how to manage his own household, how will he take care of the church of God?),
and*i not a new convert, so that he will not become conceited and fall into the condemnation incurred by the devil.
And he must have a good reputation with those outside the*i church,*i so that he will not fall into reproach and the snare of the devil.
Deacons*p likewise must*i be*i men of dignity, not double-tongued, or addicted to much wine or fond of sordid gain,
but*i holding to the mystery of the faith with a clear conscience.
These men must also first be tested; then let them serve as deacons if they are beyond reproach.
Women must*i likewise be*i dignified, not malicious gossips, but temperate, faithful in all things.
Deacons must be husbands of only*i one wife, and*i good managers of their*i children and their own households.
For those who have served well as deacons obtain for themselves a high standing and great confidence in the faith that is in Christ Jesus.
I*p am writing these things to you, hoping to come to you before long;
but in case I am delayed, I*i write*i so that you will know how one ought to conduct himself in the household of God, which is the church of the living God, the pillar and support of the truth.

By common confession, great is the mystery of godliness: He*pn who was revealed in the flesh, Was*ln vindicated in the Spirit, Seen*ln by angels, Proclaimed*ln among the nations, Believed*ln on in the world, Taken*ln up in glory.
